Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:3TD9-3400-0025-F288-00000-00Namibia wants Angola's former rebel leader to leave bush stronghold stronghold1997-05-22T00:00:00Z2020-08-04T18:48:53ZLexisNexisInternational news newsNamibia wants Angola's former rebel leader to leave bush stronghold strongholdUNITED NATIONS, May 22 22

Namibian President Sam Nujoma on Thursday appealed to Angola former rebel leader Jonas Savimbi to use the opportunity of UN protection in Luanda to take up political duties in the capital.

Speaking at a news conference here following talks with UN chief Kofi Annan, Nujoma noted that Namibian soldiers were part of the UN Angola Verification Mission known as UNAVEM III. iii.

He said one role of the 5,000-strong UN force was "to ensure that all leaders of Angola are protected."

Savimbi "should seize the opportunity of UNAVEM III because there is no better protection than UNAVEM III," said Nujoma.

"So I would hope that UNITA and especially Doctor Jonas Savimbi would return to the capital and participate meaningfully in the political activities of their country."

Savimbi, citing security concerns, has refused to leave his headquarters at Bailundo in central Angola. The swearing-in of the country's national unity government took place on April 11 without him.

Nujoma, who held talks with President Eduardo Dos Santos in Luanda last week, declined to comment on a statement earlier this week in New York by former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere about UNITA's future.

Nyerere said that in his view, UNITA, which fought alongside troops of ousted Zairean president Mobutu Sese Seko, would suffer from the loss of bases which it had used under Mobutu in the former Zaire.

Mobutu fled his central African country Friday a day before Laurent Kabila declared himself president and changed the country's name to the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

"This may be the end of UNITA, because Savimbi will no longer have bases outside Angola," Nyerere said.
